Worsening air pollution in Indian cities has significantly increased demand in the air purifiers market, as households increasingly view indoor air purification as essential rather than optional. In urban centers like New Delhi, air quality often deteriorates drastically, with recent annual mean fine particulate matter (PM2.5) levels recorded at approximately 101 g/m, more than double the national ambient air standard and several times above international health-safe thresholds. This sustained exposure to high particulate pollution has heightened public awareness of long-term health risks such as respiratory illnesses, allergies, and other pollution-related conditions prompting consumers to invest in air purifiers as a protective measure within their homes.
